results.title: The Jim Stynes story: Dublin's Jim
results.creator_credit: David Barham and Australian Football Video
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Player Profile Series”.
In the early ‘80’s the Melbourne Football Club recruited an Irish schoolboy and by the start of the next decade, Jim Stynes had taken the art of ruck play to new levels and won the Brownlow medal.

results.title: Classic Looney Tunes Cartoons
results.brief_description: Released as a 50th birthday tribute to Bugs Bunny, this series of videos are collections of classic Warner Bros. cartoons of all your favourite characters, from Daffy Duck to Porky Pig. Sit back and enjoy the fun-filled animation that is instantly recognisable and famous world-wide.

results.title: A Simple good time
results.creator_credit: Bill Steller, Chris McCullough, Australia-Japan Foundation and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journey into Japan”.
Describes the way the Japanese take holidays which are usually short and in the company of workmates. It explores their character by following a group of factory workers as they go on a weekend holiday tour of the southern island of Kyushu. We also see how weddings and honeymoons are conducted on Kyushu. Presented by Keith Adam.

results.title: The Other side of Japan
results.creator_credit: Bill Steller, Chris McCullough, Australia-Japan Foundation and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journey into Japan”.
This program, presented by Keith Adam, examines a fishing village on a remote island in the Japan sea where the traditional customs and festivals are kept alive by the villagers.

results.title: A woman's place
results.creator_credit: Stafford Garner, Chris McCullough, Australia-Japan Foundation and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journey into Japan”.
Examines how geishas are trained in song, dance, and sophisticated conversation, and how they still reign supreme as Japan’s most prestigious entertainers, as compared to women who work in clubs and bars. Geishas are employed for important functions. The program also takes a very general look at the state of women in Japan today.

results.title: The Samurai
results.creator_credit: Stafford Garner, Christopher McCullough, Australia-Japan Foundation and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journey into Japan”.
This program examines the fate of the Samurai (warrior class) when Japan modernised at the turn of the century. Keith Adam shows the making of one of the countless popular movies which recreates the Samurai and their era and postulates that the Samurai live on not only in films but also in the business and industrial life of Japan. Narrated by Keith Adam.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stafford Garner, Christopher McCullough, Australia-Japan Foundation and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: The Meiji adventure
results.creator_credit: Bill Steller, Australia-Japan Foundation and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journey into Japan”.
Presenter, Keith Adam, describes Japan’s leap from feudal outpost to modern nation by recounting the history of the Meiji dynasty that led to this amazing social transformation.

results.title: Fuji, thirty seven views
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journey into Japan”.
Once a sacred Shinto site that drew devout pilgrims, Fuji is seen to be ringed by polluting industries, littered with trash, and topped by crassly commercial souvenir stands and fast food sheds. For residents of Tokyo, Fuji used to be a daily sight; today, because of the smog, they rarely see it. Later as he explores Tokyo, Keith Adam muses on how industrial development has cut the people off from more than just the sight of Fuji but also from what it once stood for. Shinto traditions have disappeared into pragmatic secularism; close-knit, communal neighbourhoods have given way to cramped, impersonal high-rise apartments, agricultural land and open spaces are being overwhelmed by industrial plants that pollute without thought for the future. Narrated by Keith Adam.
